Abstract

Federated learning usually employs a server-client architecture where an orchestrator iteratively aggregates model updates from remote clients and pushes them back a refined model. This approach may be inefficient in cross-silo settings, as close-by data silos with high-speed access links may exchange information faster than with the orchestrator, and the orchestrator may become a communication bottleneck. In this paper we define the problem of topology design for cross-silo federated learning using the theory of max-plus linear systems to compute the system throughputâ€”number of communication rounds per time unit. We also propose practical algorithms that, under the knowledge of measurable network characteristics, find a topology with the largest throughput or with provable throughput guarantees. In realistic Internet networks with 10Â Gbps access links at silos, our algorithms speed up training by a factor 9 and 1.5 in comparison to the server-client architecture and to state-of-the-art MATCHA, respectively. Speedups are even larger with slower access links.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) â€œinvolves training statistical models over remote devices or siloed data centers, such as mobile phones or hospitals, while keeping data localizedâ€Â [56] because of privacy concerns or limited communication resources. The definition implicitly distinguishes two different settingsÂ [41]: the cross-device scenario including a large number (millions or even more) of unreliable mobile/edge devices with limited computing capabilities and slow Internet connections, and the cross-silo scenario with at most a few hundreds of reliable data silos with powerful computing resources and high-speed access links. While the first FL papersÂ [72, 51] emphasized the cross-device setting, the cross-silo scenario has become popular for distributed training among banksÂ [107], hospitalsÂ [19, 93, 69], pharmaceutical labsÂ [67], and manufacturersÂ [74].

In federated learning, clients (e.g., mobile devices or whole organizations) usually train the model through an iterative procedure under the supervision of a central orchestrator, which, for example, decides to launch the training process and coordinates training advances. Oftenâ€”e.g., in FedAvgÂ [72], SCAFFOLDÂ [45], and FedProx [57]â€”the orchestrator directly participates to the training, by aggregating clientsâ€™ updates, generating a new model, and pushing it back to the clients. Hence, clients only communicate with a potentially far-away (e.g., in another continent) orchestrator and do not exploit communication opportunities with close-by clients. This choice is justified in the cross-device setting, where inter-device communication is unreliable (devices may drop-out from training at any time) and slow (a message needs to traverse two slow access links). But in the cross-silo setting, data silos (e.g., data centers) are almost always available, enjoy high-speed connectivity comparable to the orchestratorâ€™s one, and may exchange information faster with some other silos than with the orchestrator. An orchestrator-centered communication topology is then potentially inefficient, because it ignores fast inter-silo communication opportunities and makes the orchestrator a candidate for congestion. A current trendÂ [104, 18, 100, 95, 7, 49, 53] is then to replace communication with the orchestrator by peer-to-peer communications between individual silos, which perform local partial aggregations of model updates. We also consider this scenario and study how to design the communication topology.

The communication topology has two contrasting effects on training duration. First, a more connected topology leads to faster convergence in terms of iterations or communication rounds, as quantified by classic worst-case convergence bounds in terms of the spectral properties of the topologyÂ [75, 24, 89, 90, 103, 40]. Second, a more connected topology increases the duration of a communication round (e.g., it may cause network congestion), motivating the use of degree-bounded topologies where every client sends and receives a small number of messages at each roundÂ [5, 61]. Recent experimental and theoretical work suggests that, in practice, the first effect has been over-estimated by classic worst-case convergence bounds. Reference [79] partially explains the phenomenon and overviews theoretical results proving asymptotic topology-independence [61, 81, 5]. [50, Sect. 6.3] extends some of the conclusions in [79] to dynamic topologies and multiple local updates. Experimental evidence on image classification tasks ([79, Fig. 2], [66, Fig 20.], [61, Fig. 3]) and natural language processing tasks ([61, Figs.Â 13-16]) confirms this finding. Motivated by these observations, this paper focuses on the effect of topology on the duration of communication rounds.

Only a few studies have designed topologies taking into account the duration of a communication round. Under the simplistic assumption that the communication time is proportional to node degree, MATCHAÂ [104] decomposes the set of possible communications into matchings (disjoint pairs of clients) and, at each communication round, randomly selects some matchings and allows their pairs to transmit. MATCHA chooses the matchingsâ€™ selection probabilities in order to optimize the algebraic connectivity of the expected topology. ReferenceÂ [78] studies how to select the degree of a regular topology when the duration of a communication round is determined by stragglersÂ [44, 55]. Apart from these corner cases, â€œhow to design a [decentralized] model averaging policy that achieves the fastest convergence remains an open problemâ€Â [41].

Our paper addresses this open problem. It uses the theory of linear systems in the max-plus algebraÂ [6] to design cross-silo FL topologies that minimize the duration of communication rounds, or equivalently maximize the system throughput, i.e., the number of completed rounds per time unit. The theory holds for synchronous systems and has been successfully applied in other fields (e.g.,Â manufacturingÂ [16], communication networksÂ [54], biologyÂ [12], railway systemsÂ [31], and road networksÂ [25]). Synchronous optimization algorithms are often preferred for federated learningÂ [9], because they enjoy stronger convergence guarantees than their asynchronous counterparts and can be easily combined with cryptographic secure aggregation protocolsÂ [8], differential privacy techniquesÂ [1], and model and update compressionÂ [111, 101, 88, 13].

To the best of our knowledge, this paper is the first work to take explicitly in consideration all delay components contributing to the total training time including computation times, link latencies, transmission times, and queueing delays. It complements the topology design approaches listed above that only account for congestion at access linksÂ [104] and straggler effectÂ [78].

The algorithms we propose (Sect.Â 3) are either optimal or enjoy guaranteed approximation factors. Numerical results in Sect.Â 4 show significant training speed-up in realistic network settings; the slower the access links, the larger the speedups.

2 Problem Formulation

In order to solve ProblemÂ (1) in an FL scenario, silos do not share the local datasets, but periodically transmit model updates, and different distributed algorithms have been proposed [57, 72, 58, 45, 104, 52, 103]. In this paper we consider as archetype the decentralized periodic averaging stochastic gradient descent (DPASGD)Â [103], where silos are represented as vertices of a communication graph that we call overlay. For particular choices of the matrix ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}} and the number of local updates sğ‘ s, DPASGD reduces to other schemes previously proposedÂ [61, 58, 110], including FedAvgÂ [72], where the orchestrator just performs the averaging step (this corresponds to its local loss function fi(.)f_{i}(.) being a constant). Convergence ofÂ (2) was proved in [103].

In this paper we study how to design the overlay in order to minimize the training time. While we consider DPASGD, our results are applicable to any synchronous iterative algorithm where each silo alternates a local computation phase and a communication phase during which it needs to receive inputs from a given subset of silos before moving to the next computation phase. This includes the distributed algorithms already cited, as well as push-sum training schemesÂ [5, 91, 87, 76, 23, 98, 109] and in general the black-box optimization procedures as defined inÂ [90].

2.2 Underlay, Connectivity graph, and Overlay

FL silos are connected by a communication infrastructure (e.g., the Internet or some private network), which we call underlay. For simplicity, we consider that each silo iâˆˆğ’±ğ‘–ğ’±i\in\mathcal{V} is connected to the rest of the network through a single link (i,iâ€²)ğ‘–superscriptğ‘–â€²(i,i^{\prime}), where iâ€²âˆˆğ’±â€²superscriptğ‘–â€²superscriptğ’±â€²i^{\prime}\in\mathcal{V}^{\prime}, with uplink capacity CUPâ€‹(i)subscriptğ¶UPğ‘–C_{\textrm{UP}}(i) and downlink capacity CDNâ€‹(i)subscriptğ¶DNğ‘–C_{\textrm{DN}}(i). The example in Fig.Â 1 illustrates the underlay and the other concepts we are going to define.

The connectivity graph ğ’¢c=(ğ’±,â„°c)subscriptğ’¢ğ‘ğ’±subscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{c}) captures the possible direct communications among silos. Often the connectivity graph is fully connected, but specific NAT or firewall configurations may prevent some pairs of silos to communicate. If (i,j)âˆˆâ„°cğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptâ„°ğ‘(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}, iğ‘–i can transmit its updated model to jğ‘—j. The message experiences a delay that is the sum of two contributions: 1)Â an end-to-end delay lâ€‹(i,j)ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘—l(i,j) accounting for link latencies, and queueing delays long the path, and 2)Â a term depending on the model size Mğ‘€M and the available bandwidth111 The available bandwidth of a path is the maximum rate that the path can provide to a flow, taking into account the rest of the trafficÂ [15, 39]; it is then smaller than the minimum link capacity of the path. Aâ€‹(i,j)ğ´ğ‘–ğ‘—A(i,j) of the path. Each pair of silos (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j) can use probing packetsÂ [39, 84, 38] to measure end-to-end delays and available bandwidths and communicate them to the orchestrator, which then designs the topology. We assume that in the stable cross-silo setting these quantities do not vary or vary slowly, so that the topology is recomputed only occasionally, if at all.

The cycle time is a key performance metric for the system because the difference |tiâ€‹(k)âˆ’Ï„â€‹(ğ’¢o)Ã—k|subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘œğ‘˜|t_{i}(k)-\tau(\mathcal{G}_{o})\times k| is bounded for all kâ‰¥0ğ‘˜0k\geq 0 so that, for large enough kğ‘˜k, tiâ€‹(k)â‰ˆÏ„â€‹(ğ’¢o)Ã—ksubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘œğ‘˜t_{i}(k)\approx\tau(\mathcal{G}_{o})\times k. In particular, the inverse of the cycle time is the throughput of the system, i.e., the number of communication rounds per time unit. An overlay with minimal cycle time minimizes the time required for a given number of communication rounds. This observation leads to our optimization problem.

2.4 Optimization Problem

Given a connectivity graph ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c}, we want the overlay ğ’¢osubscriptğ’¢ğ‘œ\mathcal{G}_{o} to be a strong digraph (i.e., a strongly connected directed graph) with minimal cycle time. Formally, we define the following Minimal Cycle Time problem: {problem} Note that the input does not include detailed information about the underlay ğ’¢usubscriptğ’¢ğ‘¢\mathcal{G}_{u}, but only information available or measurable at the silos (see Sect.Â 2.2). To the best of our knowledge, our paper is the first effort to study Mct. The closest problem considered in the literature is, for a given overlay, to select the largest delays that guarantee a minimum throughputÂ [28, 21].

3 Theoretical Results and Algorithms

In this section we present complexity results for Mct and algorithms to design the optimal topology in different settings. TableÂ 1 lists these algorithms, their time-complexity, and their guarantees. We note that in some cases we adapt known algorithms to solve Mct. All proofs and auxiliary lemmas are in AppendixÂ E.

3.1 Edge-capacitated networks

Remember that we call a network edge-capacitated if access links delays can be neglected, as it is for example the case whenever 1NÃ—minâ¡(CUPâ€‹(i),CDNâ€‹(j))â‰¥Aâ€‹(iâ€²,jâ€²)1ğ‘subscriptğ¶UPğ‘–subscriptğ¶DNğ‘—ğ´superscriptğ‘–â€²superscriptğ‘—â€²\frac{1}{N}\times\min\left(C_{\textrm{UP}}(i),C_{\textrm{DN}}(j)\right)\geq A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime}) for each (i,j)âˆˆâ„°cğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptâ„°ğ‘(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}. In this setting (3) becomes

doâ€‹(i,j)=sÃ—Tcâ€‹(i)+lâ€‹(i,j)+MAâ€‹(iâ€²,jâ€²),subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘€ğ´superscriptğ‘–â€²superscriptğ‘—â€²d_{o}(i,j)=s\times T_{c}(i)+l(i,j)+\frac{M}{A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime})}, (6)

and then the delay between two silos does not depend on the selected overlay ğ’¢osubscriptğ’¢ğ‘œ\mathcal{G}_{o}.

FL algorithms often use an undirected overlay with symmetric communications, i.e., (i,j)âˆˆâ„°oâ‡’(j,i)âˆˆâ„°oğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptâ„°ğ‘œâ‡’ğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptâ„°ğ‘œ(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{o}\Rightarrow(j,i)\in\mathcal{E}_{o}. This is the case of centralized schemes, like FedAvg, but is also common for other consensus-based optimization schemes where the consensus matrix ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}} is required to be doubly-stochastic [77, 87, 103]â€”a condition simpler to achieve when ğ’¢osubscriptğ’¢ğ‘œ\mathcal{G}_{o} is undirected.

When building an undirected overlay, we can restrict ourselves to consider trees as solutions of Mct (LemmaÂ E.1). In fact, additional links can only increase the number of circuits and then increase the cycle time (seeÂ (5)). Moreover, we can prove that the overlay has simple critical circuits of the form Î³=(i,j,i)ğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–\gamma=(i,j,i), for which doâ€‹(Î³)/|Î³|=(doâ€‹(i,j)+doâ€‹(j,i))/2subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘œğ›¾ğ›¾subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘—ğ‘–2d_{o}(\gamma)/|\gamma|=(d_{o}(i,j)+d_{o}(j,i))/2 (LemmaÂ E.2). Intuitively, if we progressively build a tree using the links in ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} with the smallest average of delays in the two directions, we obtain the overlay with minimal cycle time. This construction corresponds to finding a minimum weight spanning tree (MST) in an opportune undirected version of ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c}:

Proposition 3.1.

Consider an undirected weighted graph ğ’¢c(u)=(ğ’±,â„°c(u))superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ’±superscriptsubscriptâ„°ğ‘ğ‘¢\mathcal{G}_{c}^{(u)}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)}), where (i,j)âˆˆâ„°c(u)ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptâ„°ğ‘ğ‘¢(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)} iff (i,j)âˆˆâ„°cğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptâ„°ğ‘(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c} and (j,i)âˆˆâ„°cğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptâ„°ğ‘(j,i)\in\mathcal{E}_{c} and where (i,j)âˆˆâ„°c(u)ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptâ„°ğ‘ğ‘¢(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)} has weight dc(u)â€‹(i,j)=(doâ€‹(i,j)+doâ€‹(j,i))/2superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘—ğ‘–2d_{c}^{(u)}(i,j)=(d_{o}(i,j)+d_{o}(j,i))/2. AÂ minimum weight spanning tree of ğ’¢c(u)superscriptsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘ğ‘¢\mathcal{G}_{c}^{(u)} is a solution of Mct when ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} is edge-capacitated and ğ’¢osubscriptğ’¢ğ‘œ\mathcal{G}_{o} is required to be undirected.

Primâ€™s algorithmÂ [85] is an efficient algorithm to find an MST with complexity ğ’ªâ€‹(|â„°c|+|ğ’±|â€‹logâ¡|ğ’±|)ğ’ªsubscriptâ„°ğ‘ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{E}_{c}|+|\mathcal{V}|\log|\mathcal{V}|) and then suited for the usual cross-silo scenarios with at most a few hundred nodes [41].

We have pointed out a simple algorithm when the overlay is undirected, but directed overlays can have arbitrarily shorter cycle times than undirected ones even in simple settings where all links in the underlay are bidirectional with identical delays in the two directions (see AppendixÂ C). Unfortunately, computing optimal directed overlays is NP-hard:

Proposition 3.2.

Mct is NP-hard even when ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} is a complete Euclidean edge-capacitated graph.

We call a connectivity graph ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} Euclidean if its delays dcâ€‹(i,j)â‰œsÃ—Tcâ€‹(i)+lâ€‹(i,j)+M/Aâ€‹(iâ€²,jâ€²)â‰œsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘€ğ´superscriptğ‘–â€²superscriptğ‘—â€²d_{c}(i,j)\triangleq s\times T_{c}(i)+l(i,j)+M/A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime}) are symmetric (dcâ€‹(i,j)=dcâ€‹(j,i),âˆ€i,jâˆˆğ’±formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–for-allğ‘–ğ‘—ğ’±d_{c}(i,j)=d_{c}(j,i),\forall i,j\in\mathcal{V}) and satisfy the triangle inequality (dcâ€‹(i,j)â‰¤dcâ€‹(i,k)+dcâ€‹(k,j),âˆ€i,j,kâˆˆğ’±formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—for-allğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ’±d_{c}(i,j)\leq d_{c}(i,k)+d_{c}(k,j),\forall i,j,k\in\mathcal{V}). These assumptions are roughly satisfied for geographically distant computing clusters with similar computation times, as the delay to transmit a message between two silos is roughly an affine function of the geodesic distance between themÂ [32]. Under this condition Mct can be approximated:

Proposition 3.3.

Christofidesâ€™ algorithmÂ [73] is a 3â€‹N3ğ‘3N-approximation algorithm for Mct when ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} is edge-capacitated and Euclidean.

The result follows from Christofidesâ€™ algorithm being a 1.5-approximation algorithm for the Travelling Salesman ProblemÂ [73], and our proof shows that a solution of the Travelling Salesman Problem provides a 2â€‹N2ğ‘2N-approximation of Mct. Note that Christofidesâ€™ algorithm finds ring topologies.

3.2 Node-capacitated networks

When silos do not enjoy high-speed connectivity, congestion at access links can become the dominant contribution to network delays, especially when one silo communicates with many others. Intuitively, in this setting, good overlays will exhibit small degrees.

If ğ’¢osubscriptğ’¢ğ‘œ\mathcal{G}_{o} is required to be undirected, Mct can be reduced from the problem of finding the minimum bottleneck spanning tree with bounded degree Î´>1ğ›¿1\delta>1 (Î´ğ›¿\delta-Mbst for short),222 A Î´ğ›¿\delta-MBST is a spanning tree with degree at most Î´ğ›¿\delta in which the largest edge delay is as small as possible. which is NP-hard.

Proposition 3.4.

In node-capacitated networks Mct is NP-hard even when the overlay is required to be undirected.

We propose AlgorithmÂ 1 (see AppendixÂ D), which combines existing approximation algorithms for Î´ğ›¿\delta-Mbst on a particular graph built from ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c}.

Proposition 3.5.

Algorithm 1 is a 666-approximation algorithm for Mct when ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} is node-capacitated and Euclidean with CUPâ€‹(i)â‰¤minâ¡(CDNâ€‹(j)N,Aâ€‹(iâ€²,jâ€²))subscriptğ¶UPğ‘–subscriptğ¶DNğ‘—ğ‘ğ´superscriptğ‘–â€²superscriptğ‘—â€²C_{\textrm{UP}}(i)\leq\min\left(\frac{C_{\textrm{DN}}(j)}{N},A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime})\right), âˆ€(i,j)âˆˆâ„°cfor-allğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptâ„°ğ‘\forall(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}, and ğ’¢osubscriptğ’¢ğ‘œ\mathcal{G}_{o} is required to be undirected.

Finding directed overlays is obviously an NP-hard problem also for node-capacitated networks. Christofidesâ€™ algorithm holds its approximation factor also in this more general case:

Proposition 3.6.

Christofidesâ€™ algorithm is a 3â€‹N3ğ‘3N-approximation algorithm for Mct when ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} is node-capacitated and Euclidean.

4 Numerical Experiments

We adapted PyTorch with the MPI backend to run DPASGD (seeÂ (2)) on a GPU cluster. We also developed a separate network simulator that takes as input an arbitrary underlay topology described in the Graph Modelling LanguageÂ [36] and silosâ€™ computation times and calculates the time instants at which local models ğ’˜iâ€‹(k)subscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘˜{\bm{w}}_{i}(k) are computed according toÂ (2) (AppendixÂ F). While PyTorch trains the model as fast as the cluster permits, the network simulator reconstructs the real timeline on the considered underlay. The code is available at https://github.com/omarfoq/communication-in-cross-silo-fl.

We considered three real topologies from Rocketfuel engineÂ [94] (Exodus and Ebone) and from The Internet Topology ZooÂ [48] (GÃ©ant), and two synthetic topologies (AWS North-America and Gaia) built from the geographical locations of AWS data centersÂ [38, 96] (TableÂ 3). These topologies have between 11 and 87 nodes located in the same continent with the exception of Gaia, which spans four continents. We considered that each node is connected to a geographically close silo by a symmetric access link. See AppendixesÂ G andÂ H for a detailed description of the experiments and additional results.

We evaluated our solutions on three standard federated datasets from LEAFÂ [14] and on iNaturalist datasetÂ [99] with geolocalized images from over 8,000 different species of plants and animals (TableÂ 2). For LEAF datasets, we generated non-iid data distributions following the procedure inÂ [57]. For iNaturalist we assigned half of the images uniformly at random and half to the closest silo obtaining local datasets different in size and in the species represented (AppendixÂ G).

TableÂ 3 shows the effect of 6 different overlays when training ResNet-18 over iNaturalist in networks with capacities equal to 1Â Gbps and 10Â Gbps for core links and access links, respectively.333 The delay in the core network is determined by the available bandwidth as inÂ (3). Available bandwidths are often limited to tens or hundreds of Mbps even over inter-datacenter links with capacities between 100Â Gbps and 1Â TbpsÂ [38, 65, 83, 47]. By selecting 111Â Gbps core links in our simulator, which ignores other traffic, we obtain available bandwidth distributions comparable to those observed in experimental studies likeÂ [38] (AppendixÂ G). These overlays are (1)Â the STAR, corresponding to the usual server-client setting, where the orchestrator (located at the node with the highest load centralityÂ [11]) averages all models at each communication round, (2)Â a dynamic topology built from MATCHA starting from the connectivity graph, (3) one built starting from the underlay and denoted as MATCHA+ (in both cases MATCHAâ€™s parameter Cbsubscriptğ¶ğ‘C_{b} equals 0.50.50.5 as in experiments in Â [104]444 Additional experiments fine tuning Cbsubscriptğ¶ğ‘C_{b} were carried out, conclusions remain the same (AppendixÂ H.6). ), (4)Â the minimum spanning tree (MST) from Prop.Â 3.1, (5)Â the Î´ğ›¿\delta-minimum bottleneck tree (Î´ğ›¿\delta-MBST) from Prop.Â 3.5, and (6)Â the directed RING from Prop.Â 3.6. In this particular setting, Î´ğ›¿\delta-MBST selects the same overlay as MST. The consensus matrix ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}} is selected according to the local-degree ruleÂ [62].555Additional experiments were conducted selecting the matrix ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}} as solution of the fastest distributed linear averaging problem defined inÂ [62] (AppendixÂ H.4).

The overlays found by our algorithms achieve a higher throughput (smaller cycle time) than the STAR (the server-client architecture) and, in most cases, than state-of-the-art MATCHA(+). 666 As MATCHA and MATCHA(+) select random overlays at each iteration, we compute their average cycle time. In particular, the RING is between 3.3 (â‰ˆ391/118absent391118\approx 391/118 on Gaia) and 9.4 (â‰ˆ902/95absent90295\approx 902/95 on Ebone) times faster than the STAR and between 1.5 and 6 times faster than MATCHA. MATCHA+ relies on the knowledge of the underlayâ€”probably an unrealistic assumption in an Internet settingâ€”while our algorithms only require information about the connectivity graph. Still, the RING is also faster than MATCHA+ but on GÃ©ant network (where MST is the fastest overlay). From now on, we show only the results for MATCHA+, as it outperforms MATCHA.

The final training time is the product of the cycle time and the number of communication rounds required to converge. The overlay also influences the number of communication rounds, with sparser overlays demanding more roundsÂ [75, 24]. The last two columns in Table 3 show that this is a second order effect: the RING requires at most 20% more communication rounds than the STAR and then maintains almost the same relative performance in terms of the training time.777 Training time is evaluated as the time to reach a training accuracy equal to 65%percent6565\%, 55%percent5555\%, 55%percent5555\%, 50%percent5050\% and 50%percent5050\% for Gaia, AWS North America, GÃ©ant, Exodus, and Ebone networks, respectively. Note that data distribution is different in each network, so that a different global model is learned when solving ProblemÂ (1) (see explanations in AppendixÂ H.5). These results (and those in Fig.Â 2) confirm that the number of communication rounds to converge is weakly sensitive to the topology (as already observed inÂ [61, 60, 49, 66] and partially explained inÂ [86, 5, 79]). The conclusion is that overlays should indeed be designed for throughput improvement rather than to optimize their spectral properties: the topologies selected by our algorithms achieve faster training time than the STAR, which has optimal spectral properties, and MATCHA/MATCHA(+), which optimize spectral properties given a communication budget.

The same qualitative results hold for other datasets and Fig.Â 2 shows the training loss versus the number of communication rounds (top row) and versus time (bottom row) when training on AWS North America with 100 times slower access links. Other metrics for model evaluation (e.g., training/test accuracy) are shown in AppendixÂ H.2. The advantage of designing the topology on the basis of the underlay characteristics is evident also in this setting.

FigureÂ 3 illustrates the effect of access link speeds on the cycle time and the training time. When all silos have the same access link capacity (Fig.Â 3(a)), for capacity values smaller than 6Â Gbps, the RING has the largest throughput followed by Î´ğ›¿\delta-MBST, MST and MATCHA+ almost paired, and finally the STAR. The advantage of topologies with small nodesâ€™ degrees (like Î´ğ›¿\delta-MBST and the RING) is someway expected in the slow access link regime, as access link delays become the dominant term inÂ (3). In particular, Eq.Â (5) and some simple calculations in AppendixÂ B show that, with Nğ‘N silos, the RING is up to 2â€‹N2ğ‘2N (=80 for GÃ©ant) times faster than the STAR and CbÃ—maxâ¡(degreeâ€‹(ğ’¢u))subscriptğ¶ğ‘degreesubscriptğ’¢ğ‘¢C_{b}\times\max(\textrm{degree}(\mathcal{G}_{u})) (= 5 for GÃ©ant) times faster then MATCHA(+) for slow access links as confirmed in Fig.Â 3(a) (left plot). What is less expected (but aligned with our observations above about the importance to design overlays for throughput improvement) is that RINGâ€™s throughput speedups lead to almost as large training time speedups, even larger than those in TableÂ 3: e.g.Â 72x in comparison to the STAR and 5.6x in comparison to MATCHA+ for 100Â Mbps access link capacities.

When the most central node (which is also the center of the STAR) maintains a fixed capacity value equal to 101010Â Gbps (Fig.Â 3(b)), the STAR performs better, but still is twice slower than the RING and only as fast as Î´ğ›¿\delta-MBST. This result may appear surprising at first, but it is another consequence of Eq.Â (5) discussed in AppendixÂ B. Again the relative performance of different overlays in terms of throughput is essentially maintained when looking at the final training time, with differences across topologies emerging only for those with very close throughputs, i.e., MST and MATCHA+, and STAR and Î´ğ›¿\delta-MBST in the heterogeneous setting of Fig.Â 3(b).

When local computation requires less time than transmission of model updates, the silo may perform sğ‘ sÂ local computation steps before a communication round. As sğ‘ s increases, the total computation time (sÃ—Tcâ€‹(i)ğ‘ subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘–s\times T_{c}(i)) becomes dominant inÂ (3) and the throughput of different overlays become more and more similar (Fig.Â 4).888 In AppendixÂ H.1, we show tables similar to TableÂ 3 for different values of sğ‘ s. Too many local steps may degrade the quality of the final model, and how to tuneÂ sğ‘ s is still an open research areaÂ [106, 105, 102, 64, 108, 50]. Our next research goal is to study this aspect in conjunction with topology design. Intuitively, a faster overlay reduces the number of local steps needed to amortize the communication cost and may lead to better models given the available time budget for training.

5 Conclusions

We used the theory of max-plus linear systems to propose topology design algorithms that can significantly speed-up federated learning training by maximizing the system throughput. Our results show that this approach is more promising than targeting topologies with the best spectral properties, as MATCHA(+) does. In future work, we will explore how to further speed-up training, e.g., by enriching the topologies found by our algorithms with additional links that improve connectivity without decreasing the throughput, and by carefully optimizing the weights of the consensus matrix.

6 Broader Impact

We have proposed topology design algorithms that can significantly speed-up federated learning in a cross-silo setting. Improving the efficiency of federated learning can foster its adoption, allowing different entities to share datasets that otherwise would not be available for training.

Federated learning is intended to protect data privacy, as the data is not collected at a single point. At the same time a federated learning system, as any Internet-scale distributed system, may be more vulnerable to different attacks aiming to jeopardize training or to infer some characteristics of the local dataset by looking at the different messagesÂ [26, 92]. Encryption [10, 80, 8] and differential privacy [1] techniques may help preventing such attacks.

Federated learning is less efficient than training in a highly-optimized computing cluster. It may in particular increase energy training costs, due to a more discontinuous usage of local computing resources and the additional cost of transmitting messages over long distance links. To the best of our knowledge, energetic considerations for federated learning have not been adequately explored, but for a few papers considering FL for mobile devicesÂ [42, 97].

Appendix A Graph Theory

We now list concepts of graph theory which will be used later on.

  • â€¢

    Predecessor, successor, neighbour: If in a graph (i,j)âˆˆâ„°ğ‘–ğ‘—â„°(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}, then iğ‘–i is called a predecessor of jğ‘—j, jğ‘—j is called a successor of iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j, resp. iğ‘–i is called a neighbour of iğ‘–i , resp. jğ‘—j. The set of predecessors of jğ‘—j is indicated by Ï€â€‹(j)ğœ‹ğ‘—\pi(j) (or ğ’©j+subscriptsuperscriptğ’©ğ‘—\mathcal{N}^{+}_{j}), the set of all successors of iğ‘–i is denoted Ïƒâ€‹(i)ğœğ‘–\sigma(i) (or ğ’©iâˆ’subscriptsuperscriptğ’©ğ‘–\mathcal{N}^{-}_{i}) and the set of neighbours of iğ‘–i is denoted ğ’©isubscriptğ’©ğ‘–\mathcal{N}_{i}. Note that in the case of undirected graphs, ğ’©i=Ï€â€‹(i)=Ïƒâ€‹(i)subscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ‹ğ‘–ğœğ‘–\mathcal{N}_{i}=\pi(i)=\sigma(i).

  • â€¢

    Path, circuit: A path is a sequence of nodes (i1,â€¦,ip),p>1subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘1(i_{1},\dots,i_{p}),p>1, such that ijâˆˆÏ€â€‹(ij+1),j=1,â€¦,pâˆ’1formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ‹subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘1i_{j}\in\pi(i_{j+1}),j=1,\dots,p-1. An elementary path is a path where no node appears more then once. When the initial node and the final node coincide, we call the path a circuit. A circuit C=(i1,â€¦,ip=i1)ğ¶subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘–1C=(i_{1},\dots,i_{p}=i_{1}) is an elementary circuit if the path (i1,â€¦,ipâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘–ğ‘1(i_{1},\dots,i_{p-1}) is elementary, an elementary circuit is sometimes referred to as a cycle. If a cycle spans all vertices of the graph it is called a Hamiltonian cycle. The length of circuit C=(i1,â€¦,ip)ğ¶subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘–ğ‘C=(i_{1},\dots,i_{p}) is the number of the arcs of which it is composed, i.e., |C|=pğ¶ğ‘|C|=p, and its weight is the sum of the weights of its arcs, i.e, dâ€‹(C)=âˆ‘k=1pâˆ’1dâ€‹(ik,ik+1)ğ‘‘ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘1ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜1d(C)=\sum_{k=1}^{p-1}d(i_{k},i_{k+1}).

  • â€¢

    Subgraph, spanning subgraph: Given a graph ğ’¢=(ğ’±,â„°)ğ’¢ğ’±â„°\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}), a graph ğ’¢â€²=(ğ’±â€²,â„°â€²)superscriptğ’¢â€²superscriptğ’±â€²superscriptâ„°â€²\mathcal{G}^{\prime}=(\mathcal{V}^{\prime},\mathcal{E}^{\prime}) is said to be a subgraph of ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} if ğ’±â€²âŠ‚ğ’±superscriptğ’±â€²ğ’±\mathcal{V}^{\prime}\subset\mathcal{V} and â„°âŠ‚â„°â€²â„°superscriptâ„°â€²\mathcal{E}\subset\mathcal{E}^{\prime}. ğ’¢â€²superscriptğ’¢â€²\mathcal{G}^{\prime} is said to be a spanning subgraph if ğ’±â€²=ğ’±superscriptğ’±â€²ğ’±\mathcal{V}^{\prime}=\mathcal{V}.

  • â€¢

    Strongly connected graph: A digraph is said to be strongly connected or strong if for any two different nodes iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j in ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V} there exists a path from iğ‘–i to jğ‘—j.

  • â€¢

    Optimal tour: In a Hamiltonian graph (i.e., a graph having a Hamiltonian cycle) a Hamiltonian cycle with minimum weight is called an optimal tour. Finding the optimal tour in a complete graph is a well known problem and is referred to as the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP), see for example [4].

  • â€¢

    Tree, acyclic graph, and Minimum Spanning Tree (MST): A tree, or equivalently a connected acyclic undirected graph, is an undirected graph in which any two vertices are connected by exactly one path. An acyclic graph ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} is said to be a spanning tree of an undirected graph ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} if ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} is a connected spanning subgraph of ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}. ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} is said to be an MST of ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} if it has minimal weight (the weight of a tree is the sum of the weights of all its edges) among all spanning trees of ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}.

  • â€¢

    Cut, cut-set, and cut property: A cut is a partition of the vertices of a graph into two disjoint subsets. For a cut cğ‘c, the cut-set is the set of edges connecting two nodes from the two disjoint subsets. In a tree, deleting an edge, induces a partition of the set of vertices. For any cut cğ‘c of the graph, if the weight of an edge eğ‘’e in the cut-set of cğ‘c is strictly smaller than the weights of all other edges of the cut-set of cğ‘c, then this edge belongs to all MSTs of the graph.

Appendix C Directed Overlays may be Faster than Undirected Overlays

We provide two examples where the underlay network is undirected and still a directed overlay can have shorter cycle time than directed overlays. Examples are in Fig.Â 5, where numbers associated to links are the corresponding delays (in the two directions).

The ratio of the two cycle times can be made arbitrarily large.

Appendix D Approximation Algorithm for Mct on Node-Capacitated Networks

In this section, we describe AlgorithmÂ 1 that provides an approximate solution for Mct when the network is node-capacitated and ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} is complete. AlgorithmÂ 1 combines existing approximation algorithms for Î´ğ›¿\delta-Mbst on a particular undirected graph built from ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} and denoted by ğ’¢c(u)subscriptsuperscriptğ’¢ğ‘¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c} (linesÂ 1-1). LemmaÂ E.5 establishes a connection between the bottleneck of the Mbst of ğ’¢c(u)subscriptsuperscriptğ’¢ğ‘¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c} and the cycle time of Mct on ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} when the overlay is required to be undirected. To get an approximated 222-Mbst on ğ’¢c(u)subscriptsuperscriptğ’¢ğ‘¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c}, we apply the best known 333-approximation algorithm fromÂ [3, Sect.Â 3.2.1] (linesÂ 1-1) which requires ğ’¢c(u)subscriptsuperscriptğ’¢ğ‘¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c} to be Euclidean (LemmaÂ E.6), and take its result as one candidate for our solution (lineÂ 1). The cube of a graph ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}, denoted by ğ’¢3superscriptğ’¢3\mathcal{G}^{3}, is the super-graph of ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} such that the edge (uğ‘¢u, vğ‘£v) is in ğ’¢3superscriptğ’¢3\mathcal{G}^{3} if and only if there is a path between uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v in ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} with three or fewer edges. It has been proved that the cube of a connected graph is Hamiltonian and to find a Hamiltonian path in such a cube can be done in polynomial timeÂ [43]. Other Î´ğ›¿\delta-BSTs built by AlgorithmÂ 2 for 3â‰¤Î´â‰¤N3ğ›¿ğ‘3\leq\delta\leq N are considered as candidates (linesÂ 1-1) and we finally provide as solution the overlay with the smallest cycle time (lineÂ 1).

E.2 Proof of Proposition 3.2

Proposition 3.2.

Mct is NP-hard even when ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} is a complete Euclidean edge-capacitated graph.

Proof.

When ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} is an edge-capacitated graph, dcâ€‹(i,j)=sÃ—Tcâ€‹(i)+lâ€‹(i,j)+MAâ€‹(iâ€²,jâ€²)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘€ğ´superscriptğ‘–â€²superscriptğ‘—â€²d_{c}(i,j)=s\times T_{c}(i)+l(i,j)+\frac{M}{A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime})}. ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} is complete and Euclidean means that dcâ€‹(i,j)=dcâ€‹(j,i)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–d_{c}(i,j)=d_{c}(j,i), for all (i,j)âˆˆğ’±Ã—ğ’±ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ’±ğ’±(i,j)\in\mathcal{V}\times\mathcal{V} and that dcsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘d_{c} verifies triangular inequality, i.e., dcâ€‹(i,j)â‰¤dcâ€‹(i,k)+dcâ€‹(k,j)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—d_{c}(i,j)\leq d_{c}(i,k)+d_{c}(k,j), for every i,j,kâˆˆğ’±ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ’±i,j,k\in\mathcal{V}.

We consider the decision problem Mct-Decision associated to the particular case of Mct when ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} is an Euclidean edge-capacitated graph and we prove that it is NP-complete.

{problem}

We first prove that Mct-Decision is NP.101010A decision problem is NP if we can verify in a polynomial time that the answer for a given instance is YES. Several algorithms (e.g., Karpâ€™s Algorithm [20]) determines the cycle time of a given graph in a polynomial time. Thus for a proposed solution of Mct-Decision, we can compute its cycle time in polynomial time, and we can verify if the graph is strongly connected using for example depth first search. It follows that Mct-Decision is NP.

To prove that Mct-Decision is NP-complete, we show that Hamiltonian Cycle (Hc) can be reduced in a polynomial time to Mct-Decision, i.e., Hcâ‰¤pMct-Decisionsubscriptğ‘HcMct-Decision\textsc{Hc}\leq_{p}\textsc{Mct-Decision}.

Hamiltonian cycle problem is the following decision problem:

{problem}

    The case when j=v0ğ‘—subscriptğ‘£0j=v_{0} is analogous to the case when i=v0ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£0i=v_{0}.

E.4 Proof of Proposition 3.4

We prove that in a node-capacitated network, Mct is NP-hard even when ğ’¢osubscriptğ’¢ğ‘œ\mathcal{G}_{o} is required to be undirected. We start introducing the associated decision problem: {problem} Mct-U-Decision is closely related to the degree-constrained spanning tree (Dcst) defined below: {problem} Dcst is a simpler version of Î´ğ›¿\delta-Mbst, where we look for a spanning tree with degree at most kğ‘˜k and minimum bottleneck.

Dcst is NP-completeÂ [27]. For example for k=2ğ‘˜2k=2 it can be shown by a reduction from Hc.

Proposition 3.4.

In node-capacitated networks Mct is NP-hard even when the overlay is required to be undirected.

E.6 Proof of Proposition 3.6

Appendix F Time Simulator

The time simulator reconstructs the wall-clock time. It requires the complete knowledge about the underlay topology, i.e., the capacities of all physical links and the upload and download capacities for each silo. For a given overlay topology ğ’¢o=(ğ’±,â„°o)subscriptğ’¢ğ‘œğ’±subscriptâ„°ğ‘œ\mathcal{G}_{o}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{o}), the purpose of the proposed time simulator (Alg. 3) is to compute tâ€‹(k)=(tiâ€‹(k))1â‰¤iâ‰¤Nğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘–ğ‘t(k)=\left(t_{i}(k)\right)_{1\leq i\leq N}, i.e., the time at which each silo starts computing for the kğ‘˜k-th time. The simulator needs to compute the delay required to send a message with a known size on each physical link of the underlay. This delay is the sum of two termsÂ [59]:

  • â€¢

    Latency: it is the time required by the first transmitted bit to travel from the source to the destination. The latency of a link (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j) essentially depends on the length of the link and the speed of the light in the linkâ€™s transmission medium. We have estimated the latency using the formula proposed in [32]: 0.0085Ã—distanceâ€‹(i,j)+40.0085distanceğ‘–ğ‘—40.0085\times\textrm{distance}(i,j)+4, where the distance is expressed in kilometers and the latency in milliseconds. The latency of a path is the sum of the link latencies.

  • â€¢

    Transmission Delay: it is the time between the reception of the first bit of the message and the reception of the last bit. It depends on the minimum available bandwidth along the path. We compute it as M/minâ¡(CUPâ€‹(i)|ğ’©iâˆ’|,CDNâ€‹(j)|ğ’©j+|,Aâ€‹(iâ€²,jâ€²))ğ‘€subscriptğ¶UPğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ’©ğ‘–subscriptğ¶DNğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ’©ğ‘—ğ´superscriptğ‘–â€²superscriptğ‘—â€²M/\min\left(\frac{C_{\textrm{UP}}(i)}{|\mathcal{N}^{-}_{i}|},\frac{C_{\textrm{DN}}(j)}{|\mathcal{N}^{+}_{j}|},A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime})\right).

Finally, the simulator also accounts for the total time spent in computation by each node, that is the product of the number of local steps sğ‘ s and the time needed to perform one local step (in milliseconds), i.e., sÃ—Tcâ€‹(i)ğ‘ subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘–s\times T_{c}(i).

Appendix G Experiments Detailed Description

G.1 Networks and Communication model

We considered three real topologies from Rocketfuel engineÂ [94] (Exodus and Ebone) and from The Internet Topology ZooÂ [48] (GÃ©ant), and two synthetic topologies (AWS North-America and Gaia) built from AWS data centersÂ [38, 96] (TableÂ 3). For the synthetic topologies, we consider a full-meshed underlay. We assume all underlays support a shortest path routing with the geographical distance (or equivalently the latency) as link cost. These topologies have between 11 and 87 nodes located in the same continent with the exception of Gaia, which spans four continents. The GÃ©ant and Ebone network connect European cities and Exodus network connect American cities. We considered that each network node is connected to a geographically close silo by a symmetric access link.

Some underlays and examples of overlays are shown in FiguresÂ 8,Â 9, andÂ 10.

G.2 Datasets and Models

We provide full details on datasets and models used in our experiments. We use multiple datasets spanning a wide range of machine learning tasks (sentiment analysis, language modeling, image classification, handwritten character recognition), including those used in prior work on federated learning [72], and in LEAF [14] benchmark, and a cross-silo specific dataset based on iNaturalistÂ [99].

iNaturalist dataset.

iNaturalistÂ [99] consists of images from over 8,000 different species of plants and animals. We choose the dataset from iNaturalist 2018 competition which contains 450,000 images121212iNaturalist 2018 competition is part of the Fâ€‹Gâ€‹Vâ€‹C5ğ¹ğºğ‘‰superscriptğ¶5FGVC^{5} workshop at CVPR (https://github.com/visipedia/inat_comp/blob/master/2018/README.md). where the geo-locations of these images are provided. Due to a large class imbalance, iNaturalist species classification is a tough learning task, which requires large computation resources. In our experiments, we started by using a subset of the original iNaturalist dataset, selecting images containing the 808080 most popular species.131313The dataset size is reduced from 120GB to 18GB containing 67,000 images. We subsampled then 20%percent2020\% from this dataset for training. We have also conducted additional experiments on the full iNaturalist dataset, whose corresponding results are presented in AppendixÂ H.4. We refer to the complete dataset as Full-iNaturalist.

In order to simulate a realistic cross-silo environment with non-iid local datasets, one can assign the images to the geographically closest silo obtaining local datasets different in size and in the species represented. This distribution would lead some silos to have no point. We decided then to assign half of the images uniformly at random and half to the closest silo. Moreover, since most of the images in iNaturalist are from North America, for European networks such as Ebone and GÃ©ant, we mapped the European cities westward by reducing their longitude by 90 degrees. TableÂ 4 shows that our method generates quite unbalanced data distribution (e.g., for Ebone, one silo can have up to 50 times more images than another one).

To classify iNaturalist images we finetuned a pretrained ResNet-18 on ImageNetÂ [22]. In particular we used the torchvision [70] implementation of ResNet-18.

LEAF datasets.

LEAF [14] is a benchmark framework for learning in federated settings. We used three LEAF datasets in our experiments on AWS North America network where we took 20%percent2020\% of the samples randomly as our dataset.141414 Actually, the amount of data we considered is comparable to the federated learning paperÂ [56]: we considered 10 times more data for FEMNIST and the same amount of data for Sentiment140 and Shakespeare. Statistics for the corresponding data distributions are in TableÂ 5.

  • â€¢

    FEMNIST (Federated Extended MNIST): A 626262-class image classification dataset built by partitioning the data of Extended MNIST based on the writer of the digits/characters. In our experiments, we associate each silo with a random number of writers following a lognormal distribution with mean equal to 555 and standard deviation equal to 1.51.51.5.

    We train a convolutional neural network, similar to LeNet, with two convolutional layers followed by a max-pooling layer and two fully connected layers.

  • â€¢

    Shakespeare: A dataset built from The Complete Works of William Shakespeare, which is partitioned by the speaking rolesÂ [72]. In our experiment, we associate each silo with a random number of speaking roles following a lognormal distribution with mean equal to 555 and standard deviation equal to 1.51.51.5.

    We consider character-level based language modeling on this dataset. The model takes as input a sequence of 200200200 English characters and predicts the next character. The model embeds the 200200200 characters into a learnable 161616 dimensional embedding space, and uses two stacked-GRU layers with 256256256 hidden units, followed by a densely-connected layer.

  • â€¢

    Sentiment140Â [30]: An automatically generated sentiment analysis dataset that annotates tweets based on their emoticons. In our experiment, we associate each silo with a random number of Twitter accounts following a lognormal distribution with mean equal to 555 and standard deviation equal to 1.51.51.5.

    We use a two layer bi-directional LSTM binary classifier containing 256256256 hidden units with pretrained 100100100 dimensional GloVe embedding [82].

G.3 Implementation Details

Machines.

The experiments have been run on a CPU/GPU cluster, with different GPUs available (e.g., Nvidia Tesla V100, GeForce GTX 1080 Ti, and Titan X).

Libraries.

All code is implemented in PyTorch Version 1.4.0. We offer two possibilities for running the code: sequential (using only one GPU) and parallel (using multiple GPUs). In the parallel setting MPI backend is used for inter-GPU communications.

Hyperparameters.

The dataset is randomly split into an 80%percent8080\% training set and a 20%percent2020\% testing set. When training on Gaia, AWS North America, and GÃ©ant networks, the initial learning rate is set to 0.001 with Adam optimizer. When training on Exodus and Ebone networks, the initial learning rate is set to 0.10.10.1 with SGD optimizer. We decay the learning rate based on the inverse square root of the number of communication rounds. The batch size is set to 512512512 for Sentiment140 and Shakespeare datasets, to 128128128 for Femnist dataset and to 161616 for iNaturalist dataset.

Consensus Matrix.

For a given overlay ğ’¢o=(ğ’±,â„°o)subscriptğ’¢ğ‘œğ’±subscriptâ„°ğ‘œ\mathcal{G}_{o}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{o}), the consensus matrix ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}} is selected similarly to the local-degree rule in [62]. The weight on an arc is based on the larger in-degree of its two incident nodes:

ğ‘¨i,jsubscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle{\bm{A}}_{i,j} =11+maxâ¡(|ğ’©iâˆ’|,|ğ’©jâˆ’|),âˆ€(i,j)âˆˆâ„°o.formulae-sequenceabsent11subscriptsuperscriptğ’©ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ’©ğ‘—for-allğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptâ„°ğ‘œ\displaystyle=\frac{1}{1+\max\left(|\mathcal{N}^{-}_{i}|,|\mathcal{N}^{-}_{j}|\right)},~{}~{}\forall(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{o}. (22)
ğ‘¨i,isubscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ‘–\displaystyle{\bm{A}}_{i,i} =1âˆ’âˆ‘jâˆˆğ’©iâˆ’ğ‘¨i,j,âˆ€iâˆˆğ’±.formulae-sequenceabsent1subscriptğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ’©ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ‘—for-allğ‘–ğ’±\displaystyle=1-\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}^{-}_{i}}{\bm{A}}_{i,j},~{}~{}\forall i\in\mathcal{V}. (23)

The matrix ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}} so-built is symmetric doubly stochastic. The weights can be determined in a fully-distributed way: every node just needs to exchange degree information with its neighbours.

MATCHA.

We implemented MATCHA as described inÂ [104] but for one difference. In MATCHA, each matching iğ‘–i is selected independently with some probability pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i}. With probability q=âˆi(1âˆ’pi)ğ‘subscriptproductğ‘–1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–q=\prod_{i}(1-p_{i}), no matching is selected and then no communication occurs. This is equivalent to perform a random number of local steps sğ‘ s between two communication rounds. In order to compare fairly the different approaches and isolate the effect of sğ‘ s, we fixed sğ‘ s also for MATCHA as follows. Silos perform a given number of local steps sğ‘ s and then, when a communication should occur, matchings are independently sampled until at least one of them is selected. In practice, in our experiments, the probability qğ‘q was close to 0, so that the two approaches are practically undistinguishable. Finally, we observe that MATCHA computes the matchings coloring an initial topology, but it is not explained how this initial topology is selected. MATCHA and MATCHA+ operate exactly in the same way but starting from two different initial topologies: the connectivity graph ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c} and the underlay ğ’¢usubscriptğ’¢ğ‘¢\mathcal{G}_{u}, respectively. The silos can easily discover the connectivity graph ğ’¢csubscriptğ’¢ğ‘\mathcal{G}_{c}; reconstructing the underlay is much more complicated. Nevertheless, as MATCHA+ was in general outperforming MATCHA, we showed the results for MATCHA+.

Appendix H Complete Set of Experiments

H.1 Effect of the number of local steps

TablesÂ 6 andÂ 7 show the effect of 6 different overlays when training ResNet-18 over iNaturalist in networks with 1Â Gbps core links and 10Â Gbps access links and local steps equal to 5 and 10, respectively. For 555 local steps, the training time is evaluated as the time to reach a training accuracy equal to 65%percent6565\%, 55%percent5555\%, 60%percent6060\%, 45%percent4545\%, and 45%percent4545\% for Gaia, AWS North America, GÃ©ant, Exodus, and Ebone, respectively. For 101010 local steps, the training time is evaluated as the time to reach a training accuracy equal to 65%percent6565\%, 50%percent5050\%, 50%percent5050\%, 45%percent4545\%, and 40%percent4040\%, respectively.

H.2 Full results for training every dataset on AWS North America

In FigureÂ 2, we have shown the training loss w.r.t. communication rounds and wall-clock time when training four different datasets on AWS North America. Here we provide the complete results (FiguresÂ 11â€“14) which include training loss, training accuracy, test loss, and test accuracy w.r.t communication rounds and wall-clock time.

H.3 Exploring other scenarios

In our experiments, we considered 5 underlays, for which we compared 6 different overlays (e.g.,Â TableÂ 3). Moreover, we tested 4 different datasets (e.g.,Â Fig.Â 2) and 3 different values for the number of local steps s=1,5,10ğ‘ 1510s=1,5,10 (e.g.,Â TablesÂ 6 andÂ 7). We were not able to run experiments for all 360 possible combinations. In FiguresÂ 15â€“24, we show some representative additional results. For each experimental result, four metrics are shown including the train loss, train accuracy, test loss, and test accuracy w.r.t. communication rounds and wall-clock time. The common observation is that the RING converges faster than MATCHA+ and STAR in terms of wall-clock time. In some cases, the test loss and accuracy of the model learned by the RING start becoming worse after some time, with overfitting being a possible explanation in some cases (see Figs.Â 15,Â 17,Â 20, andÂ 22).

H.4 Training on Full-iNaturalist dataset

Full-iNaturalist contains 450,000 images belonging to 8142 classes. The distribution of images across classes is highly skewed. We randomly split them into an 80%percent8080\% training set and a 20%percent2020\% testing set, and fine-tuned a pretained ResNet-50 on ImageNet from torchvision implementation for species classification. When training on Gaia, AWS North America, and GÃ©ant networks, the initial learning rate is set to 5e-5 with Adam optimizer. When training on Exodus and Ebone networks, the initial learning rate is set to 0.10.10.1 with SGD optimizer. We decay the learning rate by half every epoch. The batch size is set to 969696. Because of the larger model size (161.06161.06161.06 Mbits) and larger batch size (compared with the iNaturalist setting in TableÂ 2), the computation time for one local update of the model in this case increases to 946.7946.7946.7 ms.

Half of the images are assigned uniformly at random, the other half are assigned to the geographically closest silo. TableÂ 8 shows that our method generates quite unbalanced data distributions (e.g., for Ebone, one silo can have up to 43 times more images than another one). Moreover, FigureÂ 25 shows pairwise Jenson-Shannon (JS) divergence [63] for label distributions at different silos under our method and under a uniformly random repartition. The JS divergence across silos is larger when the samples are distributed following our method, suggesting that novel data is far from being iid distributed.

Differently from the previous experiments, we did not set the consensus weights using the local degree rule, but, for a given overlay, we computed the consensus matrix ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}} with the optimal spectral properties. For undirected topologies, we solved the symmetric fast distributed linear averaging problemÂ [62, Eq.Â 17]. This problem is expressed as a semi-definite program that is convex and can be solved efficiently. For the RING, the optimal consensus matrix has all the non-zero entries equal to 1/2121/2.

TableÂ 9 shows the effect of 6 different overlays when training ResNet-50 over Full-iNaturalist in networks with capacities equal to 1Â Gbps for core links and access links.151515Training time is evaluated as the time to reach a top 5 training accuracy equal to 18%percent1818\% for Gaia and to 13%percent1313\% for other networks. The top 5 training accuracy reached by centralized training ResNet-50 after 50 epochs is about 20%percent2020\%. We can see that RING always achieves the best throughput in this setting.

H.5 Dependence of model performance on underlays

The models obtained by the experiments in TableÂ 3 have different performance w.r.t. the underlays. The reason is that we chose to optimize the mean of local functions (â€‹1â€‹)italic-(1italic-)\eqref{eq:optimization_problem_constraints}, which leads to different optimization problems when the number of silos changes. The observed difference in the trained modelsâ€™ performances is related to the fact that each of them is the result of a different optimization problem. Instead, when optimizing the weighted sum of local functions with weights equal to the percentage of the data points held by silos, the model performance does not depend on the underlay. To confirm this claim, we trained ResNet-18 on iNaturalist using the weighted average loss on STAR topology over the five underlays considered in the paper. FigureÂ 26 shows that the obtained models for these five underlays have similar performances, reaching a test accuracy between 46%percent4646\% and 48%percent4848\%.

H.6 Effect of Cbsubscriptğ¶ğ‘C_{b} in MATCHA

There is no real configuration criterion for Cbsubscriptğ¶ğ‘C_{b} in [104], but [104, Fig.Â 3] suggests to select the smallest Cbsubscriptğ¶ğ‘C_{b} that has the same spectral norm of vanilla-SGDâ€”but less communication overhead. This criterion leads to pick for all our topologies, but â€œAWS North America,â€ a value of Cbâˆˆ[0.4,0.6]subscriptğ¶ğ‘0.40.6C_{b}\in[0.4,0.6], with no significant change to the results in TableÂ 3. For â€œAWS North Americaâ€ the criterion leads to Cb=0.2subscriptğ¶ğ‘0.2C_{b}=0.2. TableÂ 10, first row, shows indeed that MATCHA is faster for Cb=0.2subscriptğ¶ğ‘0.2C_{b}=0.2, but still RING is 1.081.081.08 and 3.293.293.29 faster than MATCHA for 10Â Gbps and 100Â Mbps access links capacities, respectively. The table shows also that this criterion does not lead necessarily to the fastest training time for MATCHA. An alternative is to select Cbsubscriptğ¶ğ‘C_{b} by running time-consuming training experiments, but in any case we have always observed RING to outperform MATCHA except on GÃ©ant (see TableÂ 3 and TableÂ 10). Note that MATCHA is supposed to find by itself how often to use each link and â€œachieve a win-win in this error-runtime trade-off for any arbitrary network topologyâ€ [104]. We ran additional experiments with MATCHA over our topologies (for the RING we considered its undirected version as MATCHA uses bi-directional communications); however, MATCHA was still slower than RING (last two rows in TableÂ 10).
